newsitem.title: USA: FDA says probing death related to Ventritex device.
newsitem.headline: FDA says probing death related to Ventritex device.

text.p: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said Thursday it is investigating a report of a third death of a patient implanted with a defibrillator made by Ventritex Inc.
"We have received a report of a third death of a patient with one of the Ventritex defibrillators. We are investigating," said FDA spokeswoman Sharon Schneider.
"We do not know exactly the nature of the problem. We don't know whether this third death was caused by this same problem that appears to have caused the other two deaths," Schneider said.

Shares in Ventritex fell 1-1/4 to 18-1/8 in heavy trading late Thursday on market speculation about the death and its possible impact on Ventritex's proposed acquisition by St. Jude Medical Inc, whose shares were up 1/2 to 37-1/8.

"St. Jude's stock has been strong today and Ventritex has been sinking. So any time you see a divergence like that, it suggests the deal could be off ... I believe this deal will go through, but I think we've opened the door to a potential renegotiation of the terms," said Montgomery Securities medical technology analyst Kurt Kruger.
Ventritex and St. Jude could not be reached for comment.
St. Jude in October said it intended to acquire Ventritex in a stock swap valued at about $505 million.

On January 16, Ventritex said it had been authorized by the FDA to begin reprogramming 5,605 model V-110 and electrically similar V-112 implantable defibrillators implanted in living patients. The company said component failures in the devices were believed to be associated with the deaths of two patients.

Shares in Ventritex had been up in the mid-20s since the St. Jude bid, but in the past two weeks have fallen back. "It's been our belief since this crisis first began two weeks ago that the value of Ventritex has declined.... St. Jude could and should renegotiate the terms of this transaction," said J.P. Morgan Securities medical technology analyst Michael Weinstein.
Piper Jaffray analyst Arch Smith cautioned that the market may be overreacting to the situation. "I don't think there's going to be a repricing," he said.
